security: Recommending Mr. Christ for the Intelligence Medal of Merit reveals sensitive details of his work. For example: 'His accomplishments included the anti-disturbance mine and the time pencil, both of which are still Agency stock items, and an IR beacon' and details on audio surveillance projects. Disclosing these details of his R&D contributions could reveal specific Agency capabilities and potentially compromise ongoing or future operations and sources.
summary: This document recommends David L. Christ for the Intelligence Medal of Merit, recognizing his 20 years of meritorious service to the CIA, including his pioneering work in electronics engineering, audio surveillance, and microtechnology.
summary_one_paragraph: This is a recommendation for the Intelligence Medal of Merit for David L. Christ, who joined the CIA in November 1950 and made significant contributions over 20 years, including developing the anti-disturbance mine, the time pencil, and an IR beacon. Christ established an Applied Physics Branch, recruited graduate engineers for audio operations, and pioneered systems concepts, leading to specialized contract facilities like Baird Atomic. The recommendation also cites his exemplary conduct during a two-and-a-half-year incarceration in a denied area following apprehension on an operation in September 1960 and recognizes his leadership in over-the-horizon radar and microtechnology R&D programs, including audio surveillance countermeasures.
title: Recommendation for Intelligence Medal of Merit for David L. Christ
recipient: Head of Career Service, Deputy Director of Career Service, Deputy Director of Operating Component
sender: Robert M. Chapman, Director of Research and Development
